revision.text:
[[File:121st IOC Session logo.png|right|thumb|Logo of the 121st IOC Session.]]
The '''121st [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) [[List of IOC meetings|Session]]''' was held on October 1–9, 2009 in [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]], during which [[Rio de Janeiro]] was selected as the host city of the [[2016 Summer Olympics]].<ref name="IOC 121">{{ citation | title = Copenhagen elected as host city for the 13th Olympic Congress in 2009 | url = http://www.olympic.org/uk/news/olympic_news/full_story_uk.asp?id=1653 | accessdate = February 18, 2009 | date = 2006-02-08 | publisher = International Olympic Committee | location = [[Turin]], [[Italy]] }}</ref> The city of Copenhagen was chosen on February 8, 2006 by the 118th IOC Session held in [[Turin]], [[Italy]] to stage the [[13th Olympic Congress]], together with the meetings of the Executive Board and the 121st IOC Session.<ref name="IOC 121"/> The other candidates were [[Athens]] ([[Greece]]), [[Busan]] ([[South Korea]]), [[Cairo]] ([[Egypt]]), [[Riga]] ([[Latvia]]), [[Singapore]] ([[Singapore]]), [[Taipei]] ([[Chinese Taipei]]).<ref name="IOC 121"/> Convened on the initiative of President [[Jacques Rogge]], the 13th Olympic Congress brought together all the constituent parties of the [[Olympic Movement]] to study and discuss the current functioning of the Movement and define the main development axes for the future.<ref name="IOC 121"/>
The programme for the meeting was:<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.2009olympiccongress.com/international/en-gb/menu/home/mediacentre/programme-ioc-session-and-olympic-congress/program-ioc-session-and-olympic-congress.htm |title=Programme for the 121st IOC Session and XIII Olympic Congress |publisher=National Olympic Committee and Sports Confederation of Denmark |date=2009-08-28 |accessdate=2009-09-30}}</ref> * October 1–2: Part I of the IOC Session. The 2016 host city was announced on October 2: [[2016 Summer Olympics|Rio de Janeiro]] ([[Brazil]]). * October 3–5: [[13th Olympic Congress|The Olympic Congress]]. * October 7–9: Part II of the IOC Session. Elections for IOC President and IOC Members were held, as well as the final vote on the potential inclusion of [[golf]] and [[rugby sevens]] in the 2016 Games. Both sports were approved for the 2016 programme.
[[File:Bella Center indgang vest.JPG||right|200px|thumb|The [[Bella Center]] was the location used for the IOC Session & Olympic Congress]]
==2016 Olympic host city election==
On October 2, 2009, the [[IOC]] voted to elect the host city of the [[2016 Summer Olympics]]. [[Rio de Janeiro]] was elected host city after three rounds of voting. This was Rio's fourth bid for the Olympic Games.
{| class="navbox" style="width: 75%; align: center; font-size: 95%" |- ! colspan="5" | Election of the Host City of the [[2016 Summer Olympics]] — ballot results |- ! style="width: 25%; background-color: #ddddff" | City ! style="width: 25%; background-color: #ddddff" | Country (NOC) ! style="background-color: #f9f9f9" | Round 1 ! style="background-color: #f9f9f9" | Round 2 ! style="background-color: #f9f9f9" | Round 3 |- | style="text-align: left" | [[Rio de Janeiro]] | style="text-align: left" | {{flagIOCteam|BRA}} | 26 (27.66%) | '''46''' (48.42%) | '''66''' (67.35%) |- | style="text-align: left" | [[Madrid]] | style="text-align: left" | {{flagIOCteam|ESP}} | '''28''' (29.79%) | 29 (30.53%) | 32 (32.65%) |- | style="text-align: left" | [[Tokyo]] | style="text-align: left" | {{flagIOCteam|JPN}} | 22 (23.40%) | 20 (21.05%) | — |- | style="text-align: left" | [[Chicago]] | style="text-align: left" | {{flagIOCteam|USA}} | 18 (19.15%) | — | — |- ! style="width: 25%" | 121st IOC Session ! style="width: 25%" | Vote details ! style="background-color: #f9f9f9" | Round 1 ! style="background-color: #f9f9f9" | Round 2 ! style="background-color: #f9f9f9" | Round 3 |- | rowspan="4" style="text-align: center; center; background-color: #f9f9f9" | [[File:Olympic Rings.svg|100px|center|121st Session of the International Olympic Committee.]][[Copenhagen]] - [[Denmark]] ! style="text-align: right; background-color: #ddddff; font-size: 90%" | Eligible | 95 | 97 | 99 |- ! style="text-align: right; background-color: #ddddff; font-size: 90%" | Participants | 94 | 96 | 98 |- ! style="text-align: right; background-color: #ddddff; font-size: 90%" | Abstentions | 0 | 1 | 0 |- ! style="text-align: right; background-color: #ddddff; font-size: 90%" | Valid ballots | 94 | 95 | 98 |- ! colspan="5" | Members unable to vote |- ! colspan="2" style="background-color: #ddddff; font-size: 90%" | Members from countries with candidate cities ! colspan="3" style="background-color: #ddddff; font-size: 90%" | Other members |- | style="text-align: left" colspan="2" | {{flagicon|USA}} [[Anita DeFrantz|Anita L. Defrantz]]{{·}} {{flagicon|USA}} James L. Easton{{·}} {{flagicon|JPN}} [[Chiharu Igaya]]{{·}} {{flagicon|JPN}} [[Shunichiro Okano|Shun-Ichiro Okano]]{{·}} {{flagicon|BRA}} [[João Havelange]]{{·}} {{flagicon|BRA}} [[Carlos Arthur Nuzman]]{{·}} {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Juan Antonio Samaranch Salisachs|Juan Antonio Samaranch Jr.]] | style="text-align: left" colspan="3" | {{flagicon|BEL}} [[Jacques Rogge]] (IOC president){{·}} {{flagicon|KOR}} [[Lee Kun-hee]] (suspended){{·}} {{flagicon|GUI}} Alpha Ibrahim Diallo (absent){{·}} {{flagicon|FIN}} [[Saku Koivu]] (absent) |}
*Following Chicago's elimination, the two American IOC members were able to vote in the second and final rounds of voting. *Following Tokyo's elimination, the two Japanese IOC members were also able to vote in the final round of voting.
==New sports== The Session decided to add Rugby Sevens and Golf to the Rio 2016 program.<ref>[http://www.eurolympic.org/en/news/210-121st-IOC-Session--some-much-awaited-decisions.html "121st IOC Session: some much awaited decisions"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150521150142/http://www.eurolympic.org/en/news/210-121st-IOC-Session--some-much-awaited-decisions.html |date=2015-05-21 }}.</ref> The tally for rugby was 81 in favor, with 8 against,<ref>[http://www.worldrugby.org/olympics/history "History of Rugby in the Olympics"].</ref> and golf was approved 63–26.<ref>[http://www.pgatour.com/news/2009/10/08/olympic_announcement.html "Golf receives final approval, will be part of 2016 Olympics"].</ref> Neither sport is new to the Olympics — rugby was last featured at the Olympics [[Rugby union at the 1924 Summer Olympics|in 1924]], and golf [[Golf at the 1904 Summer Olympics|in 1904]].
==See also== * [[List of IOC meetings]] * [[117th IOC Session]] * [[123rd IOC Session]] * [[125th IOC Session]]

==External links== * [http://www.2009olympiccongress.com 121st IOC Session and XIII Olympic Congress in Copenhagen 2009]

page.title: 13th Flying Broom International Women's Film Festival

revision.text:
{{Infobox film festival | name = 13th Flying Broom International Women's Film Festival | image = 13th Flying Broom International Women's Film Festival Poster.jpg | caption = Festival Poster | number = 100 | awards = [[International Federation of Film Critics|FIPRESCI Prize]]
Young Witch Award | date = May 6–13, 2010 | location = [[Ankara]], [[Turkey]] | website = http://festival.ucansupurge.org/ | previous = [[12th Flying Broom International Women's Film Festival|12th]] | main = [[Flying Broom International Women's Film Festival|Flying Broom Film Festival]] | next = }} The '''13th Flying Broom International Women's Film Festival''' ({{lang-tr|13. Uçan Süpürge Kadın Filmleri Festivali}}) was a [[film festival]] held in [[Ankara]], [[Turkey]], which ran from May 6 to 13, 2010.{{cite web |title=Ankara’s Flying Broom festival against ‘evil’ |first= |last= |coauthors= |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-199638-ankaras-aqua-aquaflying-broom-festival-against-evil.html |work=[[Today's Zaman]] |date=2010-01-26 |accessdate=2010-08-06 }}{{cite web |title=Actress Lale Belkıs to be honored for ‘evil roles’ at Flying Broom |first= |last= |coauthors= |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-204733-actress-lale-belkis-to-be-honored-for-evil-roles-at-aqua-aquaflying-broom.html |date=2010-03-19 |accessdate=2010-08-06 }}{{cite web |title=Flying Broom festival to turn spotlight on ‘ignored identities’ |first= |last= |coauthors= |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-206955-aqua-aquaflying-broom-festival-to-turn-spotlight-on-ignored-identities.html |date=2010-04-10 |accessdate=2010-08-06 }}{{cite web |title=Flying Broom film festival takes off for women's issues in Ankara |first= |last= |coauthors= |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=flying-broom-takes-off-to-highlight-women-issues-2010-04-27 |work=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=2010-04-27 |accessdate=2010-08-06 }}{{cite web |title=Two Turkish films in the running at Flying Broom |first= |last= |coauthors= |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-208553-two-turkish-films-in-the-running-at-aqua-aquaflying-broom.html |date=2010-04-27 |accessdate=2010-08-06 }} This edition of the [[Flying Broom International Women's Film Festival]], which was founded in 1997 and is organized by Flying Broom with support from the [[Çankaya, Ankara|Çankaya]] municipality in Ankara and accredited by [[FIPRESCI]], had the theme of ''evil'' and focused on the problems of women (including prostitutes, migrant women, poor women and lesbians). The festival opened with a ceremony at the Ankara State Opera and Ballet Hall on May 6, 2010 at which honorary awards were presented to actresses [[Lale Belkıs]] and [[Gülsen Tuncer]], and art director [[Deniz Özen]], who attended the special screening of Turkish classic ''[[Unmade Bed (film)|Unmade Bed]]'' ({{lang-tr|Dağınık Yatak}}) directed by [[Atıf Yılmaz]]. Among those also in attendance at the ceremony were actresses [[Hale Soygazi]] and [[Deniz Türkali]], director [[Biket İlhan]], film critic [[Sevin Okyay]], German director [[Almut Getto]], and American director [[Nancy Schwartzman]].{{cite web |title=Women's film festival kicks off in Ankara |first= |last= |coauthors= |url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=the-biggest-women8217s-film-festival-kicks-off-2010-05-07 |work=[[Hürriyet Daily News]] |date=2010-05-07 |accessdate=2010-08-06 }}{{cite web |title=Flying Broom festival kicks off 13th edition |first= |last= |coauthors= |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-209533-aqua-aquaflying-broom-festival-kicks-off-13th-edition.html |date=2010-05-07 |accessdate=2010-08-06 }} More than 100 films were screened in 13 programmes at the Kızılırmak cinema, the Ankara Goethe Institute and the Ankara University communication faculty during the festival. A short film competition also under the theme ''evil'', whose winners were to be announced at the opening gala, and a program titled ''The Other History'', dedicated to ''ignored identities'', and featuring four recent Turkish documentaries focusing on ''identities that have been subjected to 'evil' by being deliberately alienated and ignored'' were new features of this edition.{{cite web |title=Lesser-known history unveiled at Ankara’s Flying Broom festival |first= |last= |coauthors= |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-209834-lesser-known-history-unveiled-at-ankaras-aqua-aquaflying-broom-festival.html |date=2010-05-11 |accessdate=2010-08-06 }} The festival closed with an award ceremony and screening of the winning film at the Kızılırmak cinema on May 13, 2010, at which the FIPRESCI jury, consisting of [[Ceylan Özçelik]], [[Dominique Martinez]] and [[Kirsten Liese]], awarded the festivals top prize to ''[[Home (2008 film)|Home]]'' directed by [[Ursula Meier]], and bestowed the Young Witch Award upon [[Damla Sönmez]].{{cite web |title=Meier’s ‘Home,’ Damla Sönmez win top prizes at Flying Broom festival |first= |last= |coauthors= |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-210210-meiers-home-damla-sonmez-win-top-prizes-at-aqua-aquaflying-broom-festival.html |date=2010-05-15 |accessdate=2010-08-06 }} ==Awards== ===Honour Award=== * [[Lale Belkıs]] (actress, singer and model) ===Bilge Olgaç Achievement Awards=== * [[Deniz Özen]] (art director) * [[Gülsen Tuncer]] (actress) ===FIPRESCI Prize=== * ''[[Home (2008 film)|Home]]'' directed by [[Ursula Meier]]. ===Young Witch Award=== * [[Damla Sönmez]] (actress) ==Programmes== ===Our Cinema=== * ''[[Unmade Bed (film)|Unmade Bed]]'' ({{lang-tr|Dağınık Yatak}}) directed by [[Atıf Yılmaz]]. ===Evil=== * ''[[Pomegranates and Myrrh]]'' ({{lang-ar|المر و الرمان}}) directed by [[Najwa Najjar]]. * ''[[Perfect Love]]'' ({{lang-fr|Parfait amour!}}) directed by [[Catherine Breillat]]. * ''[[Ladybird Ladybird (film)|Ladybird Ladybird]]'' directed by [[Ken Loach]]. * ''[[Dark Habits]]'' ({{lang-es|Entre tinieblas}}) directed by [[Pedro Almodóvar]]. * ''[[Or (My Treasure)]]'' directed by [[Keren Yedaya]]. * ''Fuck Me'' ({{lang-fr|[[Baise-moi]]}}) directed by [[Virginie Despentes]] and [[Coralie Trinh Thi]]. * ''[[La Cérémonie|Judgement in Stone]]'' ({{lang-fr|La Cérémonie}}) directed by [[Claude Chabrol]]. * ''[[Story of Women]]'' ({{lang-fr|Une affaire de femmes}}) directed by [[Claude Chabrol]]. ===Each Has a Different Colour=== * ''[[10 to 11]]'' ({{lang-tr|11'e 10 Kala}}) directed by [[Pelin Esmer]]. * ''[[Amreeka]]'' directed by [[Cherien Dabis]]. * ''[[Entre nos|Between Us]]'' ({{lang-es|Entre nos}}) directed by [[Paola Mendoza]] and [[Gloria La Morte]]. * ''[[She, a Chinese]]'' directed by [[Xiaolu Guo]]. * ''[[Can Go Through Skin]]'' ({{lang-nl|Kan door huid heen}}) directed by [[Esther Rots]]. * ''[[Women Without Men (2009 film)|Women Without Men]]'' directed by [[Shirin Neshat]]. * ''[[Winter Silence]]'' ({{lang-de|Winterstilte}}) directed by [[Sonja Wyss]]. * ''[[Men on the Bridge]]'' ({{lang-tr|Köprüdekiler}}) directed by [[İlksen Başarır]]. * ''[[Lourdes (film)|Lourdes]]'' directed by [[Jessica Hausner]]. * ''[[Five Days Without Nora]]'' ({{lang-es|Cinco días sin Nora}}) directed by [[Mariana Chenillo]]. * ''[[Close to You (2009 film)|Close to You]]'' ({{lang-de|Ganz nah bei Dir}}) directed by [[Almut Getto]]. * ''[[My Year Without Sex (film)|My Year Without Sex]]'' directed by [[Sarah Watt]]. * ''[[Home (2008 film)|Home]]'' directed by [[Ursula Meier]]. ===Golden Girls=== * ''[[White Material]]'' directed by [[Claire Denis]]. * ''[[Bright Star (film)|Bright Star]]'' directed by [[Jane Campion]]. ===Signe Baumane Retrospective=== * ''[[Love Story (1998 film)|Love Story]]'' directed by [[Signe Baumane]]. * ''[[The Witch and the Cow]]'' directed by Signe Baumane. * ''[[Teat Beat Of Sex]]'' directed by Signe Baumane. * ''[[Birth (2001 film)|Birth]]'' directed by Signe Baumane. * ''[[The Very First Desire]]'' directed by Signe Baumane. * ''[[Tiny Shoes]]'' directed by Signe Baumane. * ''[[Natasha (2001 film)|Natasha]]'' directed by Signe Baumane. * ''[[Signe and…]]'' directed by Signe Baumane. ===Made in Europe=== * ''[[Adoption (film)|Adoption]]'' ({{lang-hu|Örökbefogadás}}) directed by [[Márta Mészáros]]. * ''[[Take My Eyes]]'' ({{lang-es|Te doy mis ojos}}) directed by [[Icíar Bollaín]]. * ''[[Nothing (1998 film)|Nothing]]'' ({{lang-pl|Nic}}) directed by [[Dorota Kedzierzawska]]. * ''[[Broken Mirrors]]'' ({{lang-nl| Gebroken spiegels}}) directed by [[Marleen Gorris]]. * ''[[Morvern Callar]]'' directed by [[Lynne Ramsay]]. * ''[[Struggle (film)|Struggle]]'' directed by [[Ruth Mader]]. * ''[[A Common Thread]]'' ({{lang-fr|Brodeuses}}) directed by [[Éléonore Faucher]]. ===The Best...=== * ''[[The Day I Became A Woman]]'' ({{lang-fa|روزی که زن شدم}}) directed by [[Marziyeh Meshkini]]. * ''[[The Piano]]'' directed by [[Jane Campion]]. ===The Other History=== * ''[[Children Of September]]'' ({{lang-tr|Eylül Çocukları}}) directed by [[Hülya Karcı]] and [[Meltem Öztürk]]. * ''[[Brush Stroke]]'' ({{lang-tr|Fırça Darbesi}}) directed by [[Nihan Belgin]]. * ''[[Two Wisps Of Hair: The Missing Girls Of Dersim]]'' ({{lang-tr|İki Tutam Saç: Dersim'in Kayıp Kızları}}) directed by [[Nezahat Gündoğan]]. * ''[[Hush!]]'' ({{lang-tr|Nahide'nin Türküsü}}) directed by [[Berke Baş]]. * ''[[Voices (2009 film)|Voices]]'' ({{lang-tr|Sesler}}) directed by [[Filiz Işık Bulut]]. == See also == * [[2010 in film]] * [[Turkish films of 2010]] ==External links== * {{official website|http://festival.ucansupurge.org/}} for the festival ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:2010 film festivals|Flying Broom International Women's Film Festival]] [[Category:2010 festivals in Turkey|Flying Broom]] [[Category:Turkish film awards]] [[Category:Women's film festivals]] [[Category:2010s in Ankara]] [[Category:2010 in women's history]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox event | title = United Nations {{nowrap|Climate Change Conference}} | image = 2015 Climate Conference.svg | image_size = 220px | date = {{start date|2015|11|30|df=y}}–
{{end date|2015|12|12|df=y}} | place = [[Le Bourget]] in the suburbs of [[Paris]], [[France]] | coordinates = | also known as = COP 21/CMP 11 | participants = Parties to the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|UNFCCC]] | website = [http://www.cop21.gouv.fr/en Venue site]
[http://unfccc.int/meetings/paris_nov_2015/meeting/8926.php UNFCCC site] }} The '''2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference''', '''COP 21''' or '''CMP 11''' was held in [[Paris]], France, from 30 November to 12 December 2015. It was the 21st yearly session of the [[United Nations Climate Change conference|Conference of the Parties]] (COP) to the 1992 [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (UNFCCC) and the 11th session of the Meeting of the Parties (CMP) to the 1997 [[Kyoto Protocol]].{{cite web|title=19th Session of the Conference of the Parties to the UNFCCC|url=http://climate-l.iisd.org/events/conference-of-the-parties-to-the-unfccc/|publisher=[[International Institute for Sustainable Development]]|accessdate=20 February 2013}} The conference negotiated the [[Paris Agreement]], a global agreement on the reduction of [[climate change]], the text of which represented a consensus of the representatives of the 196 parties attending it.{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/12/12/world/global-climate-change-conference-vote/ |title=Final draft of climate deal formally accepted in Paris |last1=Sutter |first1=John D. |last2=Berlinger |first2=Joshua |date=12 December 2015 |website=CNN |publisher=Cable News Network, Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. |access-date=12 December 2015}} The agreement will enter into force when joined by at least 55 countries which together represent at least 55 percent of global greenhouse emissions.{{cite news |author=The Editorial Board |title=What the Paris Climate Meeting Must Do |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/29/opinion/sunday/what-the-paris-climate-meeting-must-do.html |date=28 November 2015 |work=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=28 November 2015 }}{{cite news |last=Borenstein |first=Seth |title=Earth is a wilder, warmer place since last climate deal made |url=http://apnews.excite.com/article/20151129/eu-climate-countdown-since-1997-edf9d62e51.html |date=29 November 2015 |accessdate=29 November 2015 }} On 22 April 2016 (Earth Day), 174 countries signed the agreement in New York, {{cite web|author1=Pamela Falk|title=U.S. joins 174 nations to sign hard-won climate pact|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/us-climate-pact-un-signing-ceremony-paris-agreement-cop21/|website=CBSNEWS|accessdate=9 November 2016|date=22 April 2016}} and began adopting it within their own legal systems (through [[Ratification#Ratification of an international treaty|ratification]], acceptance, approval, or accession). According to the organizing committee at the outset of the talks,[http://www.cop21.gouv.fr/en/learn/what-is-cop21/ What is COP21?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210193406/http://www.cop21.gouv.fr/en/learn/what-is-cop21/ |date=10 December 2015 }} access date 30 November 2015 the expected key result was an agreement to set a goal of limiting [[global warming]] to "well below 2 °C" [[Celsius]] compared to pre-industrial levels. The agreement calls for zero net anthropogenic [[greenhouse gas]] emissions to be reached during the second half of the 21st century. In the adopted version of the Paris Agreement, the parties will also "pursue efforts to" limit the temperature increase to 1.5 °C. The 1.5 °C goal will require zero emissions sometime between 2030 and 2050, according to some scientists. Prior to the conference, 146 national climate panels publicly presented draft national climate contributions (called "[[Intended Nationally Determined Contribution]]s", INDCs). These suggested commitments were estimated to limit global warming to 2.7 degrees Celsius by 2100.[http://newsroom.unfccc.int/unfccc-newsroom/indc-synthesis-report-press-release/ New UN Report Synthesizes National Climate Plans from 146 Countries] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208121907/http://newsroom.unfccc.int/unfccc-newsroom/indc-synthesis-report-press-release/ |date=8 December 2015 }}, UNFCCC 30 October 2015 For example, the [[EU]] suggested INDC is a commitment to a 40 percent reduction in emissions by 2030 compared to 1990.[http://www4.unfccc.int/submissions/INDC/Published%20Documents/Latvia/1/LV-03-06-EU%20INDC.pdf Intended Nationally Determined Contribution of the EU and its Member States], 6 March 2015 The agreement establishes a "global stocktake" which revisits the national goals to "update and enhance" them every five years beginning 2023. However, no detailed timetable or country-specific goals for emissions were incorporated into the Paris Agreement – as opposed to the previous [[Kyoto Protocol]]. A number of meetings took place in preparation for COP21, including the [[Bonn]] Climate Change Conference, 19 to 23 October 2015, which produced a draft agreement. {{Cite web | title = Bonn Climate Change Conference |date= October 2015 | url = http://unfccc.int/meetings/bonn_oct_2015/meeting/8924.php | website = unfccc.int | accessdate = 2015-12-15 }} ==Background== [[File:Co2-1990-2012.svg|thumb|350px|Shows the top 40 CO2 emitting countries and related in the world in 1990 and 2012, including per capita figures. The data is taken from the [http://edgar.jrc.ec.europa.eu/overview.php?v=CO2ts1990-2013 EU Edgar database].]] According to the organizing committee of the summit in Paris, the objective of the 2015 conference was to achieve, for the first time in over 20 years of UN negotiations, a binding and universal agreement on climate, from all the nations of the world.{{cite web | url=http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/french-foreign-policy-1/sustainable-development-1097/21st-conference-of-the-parties-on/article/issues-and-reasons-behind-the | title=Issues and reasons behind the French offer to host the 21st Conference of the Parties on Climate Change 2015 | publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs | date=22 May 2013 | accessdate=31 January 2014}} [[Pope Francis]] published an encyclical called ''[[Laudato si']]'' intended, in part, to influence the conference. The encyclical calls for action against climate change{{citation needed|date=November 2017}}. The [[International Trade Union Confederation]] has called for the goal to be "zero carbon, zero poverty", and its general secretary [[Sharan Burrow]] has repeated that there are "no jobs on a dead planet". ==Location and participation== [[File:JCH 6442 (22802505643).jpg|thumb|left|The heads of delegations from left to right: [[Enrique Peña Nieto]], [[François Hollande]], [[Angela Merkel]], [[Michelle Bachelet]].]] The location of UNFCCC talks is rotated by regions throughout [[United Nations]] countries. The 2015 conference was held at [[Le Bourget]] from 30 November{{cite web | url=http://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/french-foreign-policy-1/sustainable-development-1097/21st-conference-of-the-parties-on/article/france-confirmed-as-host-of-2015 | title=France confirmed as host of 2015 Climate Conference | publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs | date=22 November 2013 | accessdate=31 January 2014}} to 11 December 2015. To some extent, France served as a model country for delegates attending COP21 because it is one of the few developed countries in the world to decarbonize electricity production and fossil fuel energy while still providing a high standard of living.Guivarch, Celine and Hallegatte, S., 2C or Not 2C? 19 January 2012. FEEM Working Paper No. 87.2011. {{DOI|10.2139/ssrn.1988201}} As of 2012, France generated over 90% of its electricity from zero carbon sources, including nuclear, hydroelectric, and wind. The conference took place two weeks after a [[November 2015 Paris attacks|series of terrorist attacks]] in central Paris. Security was tightened accordingly, with 30,000 police officers and 285 security checkpoints deployed across the country until after the conference ended.{{citation |url=http://time.com/4113215/paris-attacks-climate-conference/ |title=Paris Climate Conference to Proceed with Heightened Security After Attacks |date=November 14, 2015 |last=Worland |first=Justin |publisher=Time Inc.}} The European Union and 195 nations (''see list in reference''){{cite web|url=http://unfccc.int/essential_background/convention/status_of_ratification/items/2631.php|title=Status of Ratification of the Convention|accessdate=15 Dec 2015|publisher=United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change}} were the participating parties. ==Negotiations== [[File: GUSTAVO-CAMACHO-GONZALEZ-L1060274 (23430273715).jpg|thumb|COP 21: Heads of delegations.]] The overarching goal of the Convention is to reduce [[greenhouse gas]] emissions to limit the global temperature increase. Since COP 17 this increase is set at {{convert|2|C-change}} above pre-industrial levels.{{cite web|title=Schedule of Events |url=http://unfccc.int/files/meetings/warsaw_nov_2013/application/pdf/cop19cmp9_overview_schedule.pdf |publisher=United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change |accessdate=12 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112055835/http://unfccc.int/files/meetings/warsaw_nov_2013/application/pdf/cop19cmp9_overview_schedule.pdf |archivedate=12 November 2013 |df= }} However, [[Christiana Figueres]] acknowledged in the closing briefing at the [[2012 United Nations Climate Change Conference|2012 Doha conference]]: "The current pledges under the second commitment period of the Kyoto protocol are clearly not enough to guarantee that the temperature will stay below 2 °C and there is an ever increasing gap between the action of countries and what the science tells us." During previous climate negotiations, countries agreed to outline actions they intended to take within a global agreement, by 1 October 2015. These commitments are known as [[Intended Nationally Determined Contributions]] or INDCs.{{cite web|url=http://www.wri.org/indc-definition |title=What is an INDC? | World Resources Institute |publisher=Wri.org |date=10 November 2015 |accessdate=15 November 2015}} Together, the INDCs would reduce global warming from an estimated 4–5 °C (by 2100) to 2.7 °C, and reduce emissions per capita by 9% by 2030, while providing hope in the eyes of the conference organizers for further reductions in the future that would allow meeting a 2 °C target.Nick Nuttall, [http://newsroom.unfccc.int/unfccc-newsroom/indc-synthesis-report-press-release/ Global Response to Climate Change Keeps Door Open to 2 Degree C Temperature Limit] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208121907/http://newsroom.unfccc.int/unfccc-newsroom/indc-synthesis-report-press-release/ |date=8 December 2015 }}, UNFCCC press office, 30 Oct 2015. Think-tanks such as the [[World Pensions & Investments Forum|World Pensions Council (WPC)]] argued that the keys to success lay in convincing officials in the U.S. and China, by far the two largest national emitters: "As long as policy makers in Washington and Beijing didn't put all their political capital behind the adoption of ambitious carbon-emission capping targets, the laudable efforts of other G20 governments often remained in the realm of pious wishes. Things changed for the better on 12 November 2014 when President Obama and General Secretary Xi Jinping agreed to limit greenhouse gases emissions."{{cite news |first1=M. Nicolas J. |last1=Firzli |title=Climate: Renewed Sense of Urgency in Washington and Beijing |url=http://action.shareaction.org/page/-/ClimateCapitalStewardshipFosteringMorePensionEngagement.pdf |accessdate=6 January 2016 |work=Analyse Financière| date=September 2015}} President [[Obama]] insisted on America's essential role in that regard: "We've led by example […] from Alaska to the Gulf Coast to the Great Plains [...] we've seen the longest streak of private job creation in our history. We've driven our economic output to all time-highs while driving our carbon pollution down to its lowest level in nearly two decades. And then, with our historic joint announcement with China last year, we showed it was possible to bridge the old divide between developed and developing nations that had stymied global progress for so long […] That was the foundation for success in Paris."{{cite news |author1=President Obama |title=President Obama's Statement on Climate Change |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/climate-change |accessdate=30 December 2015 |work=White House Briefing Room |date=12 December 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151228111409/https://www.whitehouse.gov/climate-change |archive-date=28 December 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ==Outcome== {{main|Paris Agreement}} On 12 December 2015, the participating 196 countries agreed, by consensus, to the final{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2015/12/12/459464621/final-draft-of-world-climate-agreement-goes-to-a-vote-in-paris-saturday |title=Nearly 200 Nations Adopt Climate Agreement At COP21 Talks In Paris|last1=Chappel|first1=Bill |date=12 December 2015 |website=NPR |access-date=12 December 2015}} global pact, the [[Paris Agreement]], to reduce emissions as part of the method for reducing greenhouse gas. In the 12-page document, the members agreed to reduce their carbon output "as soon as possible" and to do their best to keep global warming "to well below 2 degrees C".{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/cop21-climate-change-talks-saturday-announced-1.3362354 |title='Historic' Paris climate deal adopted |author=no byline |date=12 December 2015 |website=CBC News |publisher=CBC/Radio Canada |access-date=12 December 2015}} In the course of the debates, island states of the Pacific, the Seychelles, but also the Philippines, their very existence threatened by sea level rise, had strongly voted for setting a goal of 1.5 °C instead of only 2 °C.{{cite news |title=The Pacific countries that need the Paris 1.5C temperature rise agreement to 'stay alive' |date=12 December 2015 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/cop21-the-marshall-islands-and-other-pacific-countries-paris-need-the-15c-temperature-rise-agreement-a6770766.html|newspaper=Independent|location=London, England |access-date=6 April 2016}}{{cite news |title=Will '1.5 to stay alive' deal be enough to save Seychelles?|date=12 December 2015 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/dec/12/climate-change-seychelles-cop21-economy-collapse|newspaper=The Guardian|location=London, England |access-date=6 April 2016}} France's Foreign Minister, [[Laurent Fabius]], said this "ambitious and balanced" plan was an "historic turning point" in the goal of reducing global warming.{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-climatechange-summit-idUSKBN0TV04L20151212#gVKudBATCD0EGdxL.97 |title=World seals landmark climate accord, marking turn from fossil fuels |last1=Doyle |first1=Allister |last2=Lewis |first2=Barbara |date=12 December 2015 |website=Reuters |publisher=Thomson Reuters |access-date=12 December 2015}} However, some others criticized the fact that significant sections are "promises" or aims and not firm commitments by the countries.{{cite news |last=Milman |first=Oliver |date=12 December 2015 |title=James Hansen, father of climate change awareness, calls Paris talks 'a fraud' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/dec/12/james-hansen-climate-change-paris-talks-fraud |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London, England |access-date=14 December 2015}} ===Non-binding commitments, lack of enforcement mechanisms=== The Agreement will not become binding on its member states until 55 parties who produce over 55% of the world's greenhouse gas have ratified the Agreement. There is doubt whether some countries, especially the United States,{{cite news |last=Pengelly |first=Martin |date=December 12, 2015 |title=Obama praises Paris climate deal as 'tribute to American leadership' |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/dec/12/obama-speech-paris-climate-change-talks-deal-american-leadership |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London, England |access-date=December 12, 2015}} will agree to do so, though the United States publicly committed, in a joint Presidential Statement with China, to joining the Agreement in 2016. Each country that ratifies the agreement will be required to set a target for emission reduction or limitation, called a "nationally determined contribution," or "NDC," but the amount will be voluntary.{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/12/12/world/global-climate-change-conference-vote/index.html?eref=rss_topstories |title=Obama: Climate agreement 'best chance we have' to save the planet |last1=Sutter |first1=John D. |last2=Berlinger |first2=Joshua |date=December 12, 2015 |website=CNN |publisher=CNN Network, Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. |access-date=December 12, 2015}} There will be neither a mechanism to force {{cite news |last=Reguly |first=Eric |date=14 December 2015 |title=Paris climate accord marks shift toward low-carbon economy |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/optimism-in-paris-as-final-draft-of-global-climate-deal-tabled/article27739122/ |newspaper=Globe and Mail |location=Toronto, Canada |access-date=14 December 2015}} a country to set a target by a specific date nor enforcement measures if a set target is not met.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-35092127 |title=COP21: What does the Paris climate agreement mean for me? |first=Mark |last=Kinver |date=14 December 2015 |website=BBC News |publisher=BBC |access-date=14 December 2015}}{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/13/world/europe/climate-change-accord-paris.html |title=Nations Approve Landmark Climate Accord in Paris |last=Davenport |first=Coral |date=12 December 2015 |website=New York Times |publisher=New York Times |access-date=14 December 2015}} There will be only a "name and shame" system{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india/paris-climate-deal-what-the-agreement-means-for-india-and-the-world/story-U7TWH8dusBqRV8pzmqDG8M.html|title=Paris climate deal: What the agreement means for India and the world|accessdate=14 December 2015|date=14 December 2015|work=[[Hindustan Times]]}} or, as [[János Pásztor (diplomat)|János Pásztor]], the U.N. assistant secretary-general on climate change, told [[CBS News]], a "name and encourage" plan.{{cite web |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/cop21-climate-change-conference-final-draft-historic-plan/ |title=Climate negotiators strike deal to slow global warming |author=no byline |date=12 December 2015 |website=CBS News |publisher=CBS Interactive Inc. |access-date=14 December 2015}} Some analysts have also observed that the stated objectives of the Paris Agreement are implicitly "predicated upon an assumption – that [[member states of the United Nations]], including high polluters such as China, US, India, Canada, Russia, Indonesia and Australia, which generate more than half the world's greenhouse gas emissions, will somehow drive down their carbon pollution voluntarily and assiduously without any binding enforcement mechanism to measure and control CO2 emissions at any level from factory to state, and without any specific penalty gradation or fiscal pressure (for example a [[carbon tax]]) to discourage bad behaviour."{{cite news|author1=M. Nicolas J. Firzli |title=Investment Governance: The Real Fight against Emissions is Being Waged by Markets|url= http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2016-01-25/un-climate-conference-cop21-laurent-fabius-carbon-emissions-calpers-calstrs|work=Dow Jones Financial News|date=25 January 2016}} ===Institutional investors' contribution to limiting fossil fuels=== Speaking at the [[World Pensions & Investments Forum|5th annual World Pensions Forum]] held on the sidelines of the COP21 Summit, [[Earth Institute]] Director [[Jeffrey Sachs]] argued that [[institutional investor]]s would eventually divest from carbon-reliant firms if they could not react to political and regulatory efforts to halt climate change: "Every energy company in a [[pension fund]]'s portfolio needs to be scrutinized from purely a financial view about its future, 'Why is this [a company] we would want to hold over a five- to 20-year period?'... If we continue to hold major energy companies that don't have an answer to a basic financial test, we are just gambling. We have to take a [[fiduciary]] responsibility – these are not good bets."{{cite news|author1=Andrew Pearce|title= Jeffrey Sachs: Fund Managers Have a Duty to Dump Fossil Fuels|url=http://www.efinancialnews.com/story/2015-12-07/sachs222 |accessdate=16 December 2015|work=Financial News|date=6 December 2015}} Some US policy makers concurred, notably [[Al Gore]], insisting that "no agreement is perfect, and this one must be strengthened over time, but groups across every sector of society will now begin to reduce dangerous carbon pollution through the framework of this agreement."{{cite news|author1=John Vidal|title= Paris Climate Agreement 'May Signal End of Fossil Fuel Era'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/dec/13/paris-climate-agreement-signal-end-of-fossil-fuel-era|accessdate=16 December 2015|work=The Guardian|date=13 December 2015}} == Declarations of non-state parties== [[File:-1heart1tree - Tour Eiffel à -Paris - Eiffel Tower - COP 21 (22779585433).jpg|thumb|[[Eiffel Tower]] illuminated in green in response to the ''One heart, One tree'' campaign]] As is usual before such major conferences, major NGOs and groups of governments have drafted and published a wide variety of declarations they intend to seek a consensus on, at the Paris conference itself. These include at least the following major efforts: *[[ICLEI]] at its World Congress, launched the new '''Transformative Actions Program (TAP)''' intended to progress local and subnational action ahead of COP21{{cite web |url=http://www.transport2020.org/newsitem/3286/iclei-world-congress-2015-sees-mayors-commit-ahead-of-paris-cop-21 |title=ICLEI World Congress 2015 sees Mayors commit ahead of Paris COP 21 - Bridging the Gap |publisher=Transport2020.org |date=15 April 2015 |accessdate=15 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117030537/http://www.transport2020.org/newsitem/3286/iclei-world-congress-2015-sees-mayors-commit-ahead-of-paris-cop-21 |archive-date=17 November 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} to build on its 2005 COP11 (Montreal summit) commitments,{{cite web|url=http://archive.iclei.org/documents/events/montreal_summit/declaration/World_Mayors_and_Municipal_Leaders_Declaration_on_Climate_Change_English.pdf |format=PDF |title=World Mayors and Municipal Leaders Declaration on Climate Change |publisher=Archive.iclei.org |accessdate=15 November 2015}} [[Triple Bottom Line]] framework arising from that, and other local efforts. **''European capital and large cities for climate action en route to COP 21 Declaration'', adopted 26 March 2015 by "representatives of EU capitals and large cities of 28 EU Member States at the Mayors Meeting organized by [[Anne Hidalgo]], Mayor of Paris, and [[Ignazio Marino]], Mayor of Rome, who argue that "urban areas exposed to climate change are also essential innovation testing zones",{{cite web|url=http://www.stadtentwicklung.berlin.de/service/gesetzestexte/de/download/beschaffung/2015_03_declaration_en.pdf |format=PDF |title=European capital and large cities for climate action en route to COP 21 |publisher=Stadtentwicklung.berlin.de |accessdate=15 November 2015}} which is the focus of the ICLEI mechanisms, metrics and 2005 declaration. *Private, corporate and private-public partnerships **At the World Summit of Regions for Climate (WSRC) in Paris 2014, [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], the Founder of [[R20 Regions of Climate Action|R20]], invited a coalition of governments, businesses and investors to sign a draft "Paris Declaration" at World Climate Summit in Lima 2014, World Green Economy Summit 2015 in Dubai and COP21.{{cite web |url=http://regions-climate.org/declaration/ |title=World Summit of Regions for Climate |publisher=Regions-climate.org |date=11 October 2014 |accessdate=15 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117025629/http://regions-climate.org/declaration/ |archive-date=17 November 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} **'''The Shift project''' by French business organizations.{{cite web|url=http://theshiftproject.org/this-article/the-shift-project-signs-a-declaration-in-preparation-for-the-cop-21 |title=signs a declaration in preparation for the COP 21 |publisher=The Shift Project |date=17 July 2014 |accessdate=15 November 2015}} *[[Indigenous peoples]] efforts include: **'''Asian indigenous peoples declaration'''{{cite web |url=http://www.aippnet.org/index.php/statements/1565-asia-indigenous-peoples-declaration-on-the-21st-session-of-the-unfccc-conference-of-parties-cop21 |title=Asia Indigenous Peoples' Declaration on the 21st Session of the UNFCCC-Conference of Parties (COP21) |publisher=Aippnet.org |date= |accessdate=15 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117022057/http://www.aippnet.org/index.php/statements/1565-asia-indigenous-peoples-declaration-on-the-21st-session-of-the-unfccc-conference-of-parties-cop21 |archive-date=17 November 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} **[[IPACC]] acting for African indigenous peoples{{cite web |url=http://www.ipacc.org.za/eng/default.asp |title=Indigenous Peoples of Africa Co-ordinating Committee |publisher=IPACC |date= |accessdate=15 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117023807/http://www.ipacc.org.za/eng/default.asp |archive-date=17 November 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} in particular but also worldwide{{cite web|url=http://ipcca.info/ipcca-note-looking-ahead-cop21-state-of-negotiations-on-the-indigenous-peoples-agenda |title=Looking ahead COP21: State of negotiations on the Indigenous Peoples' agenda |publisher=Ipcca.info |date=11 September 2015 |accessdate=15 November 2015}} **A vast range of groups and peoples "seeking presence in post-2015" development, e.g. the Centre for Autonomy and Development of Indigenous People in Nicaragua{{cite web|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2014/09/indigenous-peoples-seek-presence-in-post-2015-development-agenda/ |title=Indigenous Peoples Seek Presence in Post-2015 Development Agenda | Inter Press Service |publisher=Ipsnews.net |date=4 September 2014 |accessdate=15 November 2015}} **Many indigenous polities and sovereignties seeking recognition under the [[Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples]]{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/esa/socdev/unpfii/documents/DRIPS_en.pdf |format=PDF |title=United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples |publisher=Un.org |accessdate=15 November 2015}} who demanded recognition and change also in 2014 at the [[2014 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] in Lima.{{cite web|url=http://www.forestpeoples.org/topics/un-framework-convention-climate-change-unfccc/news/2014/12/summary-indigenous-people-s-demand |title=Summary of Indigenous People's Demands for UNFCCC CoP20, Lima, Peru | Forest Peoples Programme |publisher=Forestpeoples.org |date=1 December 2014 |accessdate=15 November 2015}} In 2015 this will include those with specific grievances, e.g. the [[Wabanaki Confederacy]] in its opposition to [[hydraulic fracturing]] and [[Energy East]], has announced it will send a diplomatic representative regarding events in 2013 in [[New Brunswick]] that highlighted the relative imbalance of power to resist [[fossil fuel]] corporations even on unceded lands: ***"Canada is the home to 75% of the worlds {{sic}} mining corporations, and they have tended to have relative impunity in the Canadian Courts" - [[Winona LaDuke]]{{cite web|author= |url=http://earthfirstjournal.org/newswire/2013/07/02/when-drones-guard-the-pipeline-militarizing-fossil-fuels-in-the-east/ |title=When Drones Guard the Pipeline: Militarizing Fossil Fuels in the East | Earth First! Newswire |publisher=Earthfirstjournal.org |date= |accessdate=15 November 2015}} *'''Women's Earth and Climate Action Network''' seeking "powerful submissions by worldwide women" sharing "stories, struggles, solutions and action plans ... [a] women's climate justice mobilization"{{cite web|url=http://wecaninternational.org/pages/global-womens-climate-justice-mobilization |title=Global Women's Climate Justice Day of Action - Sept. 29, 2015 | WECAN |publisher=Wecaninternational.org |date=29 September 2015 |accessdate=15 November 2015}} *'''Countries of the Mediterranean Sea.''' Dam Bridge, Strait of Gibraltar, S.A. (PPEGSA). The first draft [http://www.presapuente.com PresaPuente] adapting to climate change is designed to protect the Mediterranean from the imminent rising waters caused by the polar thaw. More than 24 countries, over 500 million people, more than 15,000 islands and thousands of kilometres of coast which can be saved from flooding. *[[Sunshine countries|'''Solar alliance''']]: Indian Prime Minister [[Narendra Modi]] announced at the 2015 G-20 Summit that he, along with French President [[François Hollande]], intends to propose creating an alliance of solar-rich countries similar to the [[Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries]] (OPEC).{{cite web|url=http://www.firstpost.com/world/g20-summit-modi-pushes-for-100-bn-finances-to-pursue-clean-energy-proposes-grand-global-solar-alliance-2507518.html |title=G20 summit: Modi pushes for $100 bn finances to pursue clean energy, proposes grand global solar alliance |publisher=Firstpost |date=15 November 2015 |accessdate=30 November 2015}}{{cite news |url=http://www.firstpost.com/fwire/india-should-take-initiatives-to-form-league-like-opec-modi-281550.html |title=India should take initiatives to form league like OPEC: Modi |agency=Charanka |date=19 April 2012 |accessdate=30 November 2015}} Ahead of the climate summit, the two leaders sent written invitations to over 100 countries to join the coalition proposed to be called the International Agency for Solar Policy and Application (InSPA).{{cite web|author= |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/economy/policy/narendra-modi-francois-hollande-invite-over-100-countries-for-solar-alliance/articleshow/49925633.cms |title=Narendra Modi, Francois Hollande invite over 100 countries for solar alliance |publisher=Economictimes.indiatimes.com |date=25 November 2015 |accessdate=30 November 2015}} *A vast range of other activities{{cite web|last=Bisiaux |first=Alice |url=http://climate-l.iisd.org/events/unfccc-cop-21/ |title=Event: UNFCCC COP 21 | Climate Change Policy & Practice | IISD Reporting Services |publisher=Climate-l.iisd.org |date= |accessdate=15 November 2015}} in preparation to influence the major decisions at the conference. ==Financing== [[File:Greenpeace Climate March 2015 Madrid.jpg|thumb|Greenpeace activists, demanding 100% [[renewable energy]] at Climate March 2015 in Madrid.]] The conference was budgeted to cost [[€]]170m ([[US$]]186.87m at the time). The French government said that 20% of the cost would be borne by French firms such as [[Électricité de France|EDF]], [[Engie]] (formerly known as GDF Suez), [[Air France]], [[Renault-Nissan]] and [[BNP Paribas]].{{cite news|author1=Arthur Neslen|title=France defends 'imperfect' fossil fuel sponsors for Paris climate summit|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/may/29/paris-climate-summit-sponsors-include-fossil-fuel-firms-and-big-carbon-emitters|accessdate=23 September 2015|work=The Guardian|date=29 May 2015|quote=guard}} ==Demonstrations== Around the world, 600,000 took part in demonstrations in favour of a strong agreement, such as the [[Global Climate March]] organized by [[350.org]] (and other events such as [[Alternatiba, Village of Alternatives]]). Paris had a ban on public gatherings in the wake of [[November 2015 Paris attacks|recent terrorist attacks]] ([[State of emergency in France|state of emergency]]), but allowed thousands to demonstrate on 12 December against what they felt was a too-weak treaty.Organisers of events include [http://anv-cop21.org/ Non-violent action COP21], see {{YouTube|hhxPRGp-5jo|Rassemblement Champ-de-Mars 12 décembre 2015 [Gathering at the Champ-de-Mars on 12 December 2015]}}. One of the slogan was "État d'urgence climatique" (state of climate emergency). There was also an illegal demonstration in Paris, including violent clashes between police and anarchists, ten policemen were injured and 317 people arrested.[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/live/2015/nov/29/global-peoples-climate-change-march-2015-day-of-action-live Global climate march 2015: hundreds of thousands march around the world – as it happened], 21:43, ''[[The Guardian]]''. Accessed 13 Dec 2015.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/12/13/world/europe/climate-activists-gather-in-paris-to-protest-outcome-of-conference.html|title=Protesters Are in Agreement as Well: Pact Is Too Weak|last=Rubin|first=Alissa J.|date=2015-12-12|last2=Peltier|first2=Elian|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-07-10}} ==See also== {{div col}} * [[Environmental politics]] * [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report]] * [[Paris Agreement]] * [[Politics of global warming]] * [[Post–Kyoto Protocol negotiations on greenhouse gas emissions]] * ''[[The Standing March]]'' {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em|refs= {{cite web|title=Adoption of the Paris agreement – by the President – Draft decision -/CP.21 |work= |publisher=[[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|UNFCCC]] |date=2015-12-12 |url=http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2015/cop21/eng/l09r01.pdf |format=[[Portable Document Format|PDF]] |doi= |accessdate=2015-12-12 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6djDMHZAT?url=http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2015/cop21/eng/l09r01.pdf |archivedate=12 December 2015 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} }} ==External links== {{Commons category|2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference}} * [http://unfccc6.meta-fusion.com/cop21/events COP21 On Demand video overview] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150227165317/http://www.cop21.gouv.fr/en Official French website] * [http://unfccc.int/meetings/paris_nov_2015/meeting/8926.php Official UN website] * [http://www.cop21paris.org/ Official Paris Climate Conference] * {{cite news |last=Gillis |first=Justin |date=November 28, 2015 |title=Short Answers to Hard; Questions About Climate Change |url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/11/28/science/what-is-climate-change.html |newspaper=NYT |access-date=August 10, 2016}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0GQfe6r6w2I&list=PL717E307DE4DD6C6C&index=1 COP21 questions and answers. Video by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7GICzLb1d0M Why COP21 matters, and how climate change impacts sustainable development. Video by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)] * [http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/presscenter/events/2015/december/COP21-paris-climate-conference.html Background on COP21 from the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)] * [https://works.bepress.com/bryan_druzin/18/download/ A Plan to strengthen the Paris Agreement] * [http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/sotc/ NOAA State of the Climate] {{United Nations climate change conferences|state=collapsed}} {{Global warming|state=collapsed}} {{Portal bar|2010s|Global warming|Paris|United Nations|International relations|2010s}} {{DEFAULTSORT:United Nations Climate Change Conference}} [[Category:2015 conferences]] [[Category:2015 in the environment]] [[Category:2015 in Paris]] [[Category:Climate change policy]] [[Category:Conferences in Paris]] [[Category:Global warming|2015]] [[Category:United Nations climate change conferences|2015]] [[Category:United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|2015]] [[Category:November 2015 events in Europe]] [[Category:December 2015 events in Europe]] [[Category:Events in Paris]]

{{Infobox award | name = 36th Primetime Emmy Awards | image = | caption = | date = {{unbulleted list | September 23, 1984
{{small|(Ceremony)}} | September 16, 1984
{{small|(Creative Arts Awards)}} }} | location = [[Pasadena Convention Center|Pasadena Civic Auditorium]], [[Pasadena, California]] | presenter = [[Academy of Television Arts and Sciences]] | host = [[Tom Selleck]] | network = [[CBS]] | producer = | previous = [[35th Primetime Emmy Awards|35th]] | main = {{nowrap|[[Primetime Emmy Award]]s}} | next = [[37th Primetime Emmy Awards|37th]] }} The '''36th Primetime Emmy Awards''' were held on September 23, 1984. The ceremony was broadcast on [[CBS]], from the [[Pasadena Civic Auditorium]], [[Pasadena, California]]. The top shows of the night were ''[[Cheers]]'' and ''[[Hill Street Blues]]''. ''Cheers'' won its second straight Emmy for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Comedy Series|Outstanding Comedy Series]], while ''Hill Street Blues'' made history. It became the first show to win the Emmy for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Drama Series|Outstanding Drama Series]] four consecutive years. This record still stands today, but has been tied twice, by ''[[The West Wing]]'' and ''[[Mad Men]]''. ''Hill Street Blues'' also added to another streak. It received at least 14 major nominations for the fourth straight year, winning four. ''Cheers'' received the most nominations on the comedy side (10), winning three. [[Laurence Olivier|Sir Laurence Olivier]] won the last of his five career Emmys this evening. His win was also the last time a [[Broadcast syndication|non-Network Syndicated]] performance won an Acting Award. ==Winners and nominees== [http://www.emmys.com/awards/nominees-winners/1984 Emmys.com list of 1984 Nominees & Winners] ===Programs=== {| class="wikitable" width="100%" |- !
